Problem Transformation Methods¶

Problem transformation methods reduce the problem of multi-label classification into a number of easier problems, for example binary or multi-class classification.

class skml.problem_transformation.LabelPowerset(estimator)[source]¶

Implements the label powerset problem transformation strategy, where for each possible subset of the label powerset a classifier is trained, which classifies whether or not the label subset should be assigned to the given instance or not.

Methods

__init__(estimator)[source]¶

Creates label powersets for the given labels. Each powerset is transformed into a single label, resulting in a multi-class classification problem. For labels, this meta estimator generates labels.

Note, that rare label combinations result in a small number of samples for a given label after the transformation. This might result in rather bad learning effects for the combination given by the label powerset. Also, the computational complexity is exponential, hence for many labels the label powerset increases notably, and might result in computational problems.

Parameters:

estimator : scikit-learn compatible classifier instance. Will be

copied (with all hyperparameters) before use, hence will be left untouched.
Returns:

label powerset transformed multi-class meta estimator
fit(X, y)[source]¶

Fit underlying estimators.

Parameters:

X : (sparse) array-like, shape = [n_samples, n_features]

Data.

y : (sparse) array-like, shape = [n_samples, ], [n_samples, n_classes]

Multi-label targets.
predict(X)[source]¶

Predicts the labels for the given instances.

Parameters:

Data.
Returns:

array-like, shape = [n_samples, n_labels]

Estimated labels
class skml.problem_transformation.BinaryRelevance(estimator)[source]¶

Implements the binary relevance problem transformation strategy, where for each label a distinct binary classifier is trained to classify whether the instance should be part of the class or not.

Methods

__init__(estimator)[source]¶

Constructs a classifier for each single label, thus having n_labels estimators predicting a single label for an instance.

Parameters:

classifier : scikit-learn compatible classifier instance. Will be

copied (with all hyperparameters) before use, hence will be left untouched.

number_of_chains : Number of chains the ensemble shall train

threshold : Decision threshold to assign a label or not. Has to be

between 0 and 1.

max_features : Number of features to draw from.
Returns:

ensemble classifier chain instance
fit(X, y)[source]¶

Fit underlying estimators.

Parameters:

X : (sparse) array-like, shape = [n_samples, n_features]

Data.

y : (sparse) array-like, shape = [n_samples, ], [n_samples, n_classes]

Multi-label targets.

Estimated labels
predict_proba(X)[source]¶

Predicts the label probabilites for the given instances. Note that these probabilities might not be obtainable, depending on the used classifiers. They also might have to be calibrated.

Parameters:

X : (sparse) array-like, shape = [n_samples, n_features]

Data.
Returns:

array-like, shape = [n_samples, n_labels]

Estimated labels
class skml.problem_transformation.ClassifierChain(estimator, threshold=0.5)[source]¶

This classifier constructs a chain of classifiers for multi-label classification (MLC). For each label (which ought to be given as a binary label indicator vector, where 0 stands for “instance does not have label, 1 otherwise”) a classifier is trained. The classifier predicts one label, and one only (called binary relevance). The first classifier predicts the first label of the label vector (which outputs 0 or 1), whereas the second predicts the second label, but the first label is appended to the feature vector (X[i]). The n-th classifier predicts the n-th label given the feature vector, where the (n-1)-th labels are appended to.

Methods

__init__(estimator, threshold=0.5)[source]¶

Classifer Chain multi-label strategy

Builds a new classifier chain using the given classifier, which is copied times (L is the set of labels).

Parameters:classifier : The classifier used to build a chain of classifiers.

Fit underlying estimators.

Parameters:

predict_proba(X)[source]¶

Predicts the label probabilites for the given instances. Note that these probabilities might not be obtainable, depending on the used classifiers. They also might have to be calibrated, in order to get proper probabilities.

Parameters:

X : (sparse) array-like, shape = [n_samples, n_features]

Data.
Returns:

array-like, shape = [n_samples, n_labels]

Estimated labels
